A 'high confidence' rating does not imply fact or complete certainty however, and such judgements still carry the risk of being wrong.</td>

                                                        <th id="pageContent_thConsiderableDanger" scope="row" class="considerableDangerBg">Considerable</th>
	
                                                        <td colspan="2">
                                                            <ul class='dangerDefinitionList'><li>Dangerous avalanche conditions. Careful snowpack evaluation, cautious route-finding and conservative decision-making essential.</li><li>Natural avalanches possible; human-triggered avalanches likely.</li><li>Small avalanches in many areas; or large avalanches in specific areas; or very large avalanches in isolated areas.</li></ul></td>

                                                    </tr>
                                                    <tr>
                                                        <th id="pageContent_thHighDanger" scope="row" class="highDangerBg">High</th>
	
                                                        <td colspan="2">
                                                            <ul class='dangerDefinitionList'><li>Very dangerous avalanche conditions. Travel in avalanche terrain not recommended.</li><li>Natural avalanches likely; human-triggered avalanches very likely.</li><li>Large avalanches in many areas; or very large avalanches in specific areas.</li></ul></td>

                                                    </tr>
                                                    <tr>
                                                        <th id="pageContent_thExtremeDanger" scope="row" class="extremeDangerBg">Extreme</th>
	
                                                        <td colspan="2">
                                                            <ul class='dangerDefinitionList'><li>Avoid all avalanche terrain.</li><li>Natural and human-triggered avalanches certain.</li><li>Large to very large avalanches in many areas.</li></ul></td>
                                                    </tr>
                                                </tbody>
                                            </table>
                                        </div>
                                    </div>
                                    <div id="pageContent_pnlProblemsBox">
		
                                        
                                                <section>
                                            
                                                
                                                <div id="pageContent_rptProblem_pnlProblem_0" class="well">
			
                                                    
                                                    <div class="row">
                                                        <h4 class="problemheader"><span id="pageContent_rptProblem_lblProblem_0">Problem&nbsp;1: Wind Slabs</span></h4>
                                                        <div class="col-md-6">
                                                            <div class="row">
                                                                <div class=" problemImageBox elevationImageBox col-xs-6">
                                                                    <div class="problemImageTitle nowrap">
                                                                        <span id="pageContent_rptProblem_lblElevation_0">Which Elevation?</span>
                                                                    </div>
                                                                    <img id="pageContent_rptProblem_imgElevation_0" title="Which Elevation? alpine, treeline" class="img-responsive problemImages" src="Resources/Images/Elevation/Elevation-0-1-1_en.png" alt="Which Elevation? alpine, treeline" width="200" />
                                                                </div>
                                                                <div class="problemImageBox compassImageBox  col-xs-6">
                                                                    <div class="problemImageTitle nowrap">
                                                                        <span id="pageContent_rptProblem_lblAspect_0">Which Slopes?</span>
                                                                    </div>
                                                                    <img id="pageContent_rptProblem_imgAspect_0" title="Which Slopes? north, northeast, east, southeast, northwest, south" class="img-responsive problemImages" src="Resources/Images/Compass/compass-1-1-1-1-1-0-0-1_en.png" alt="Which Slopes? north, northeast, east, southeast, northwest, south" width="130" />
                                                                </div>
                                                            </div>
                                                        </div>
                                                        <div class="col-md-6">
                                                            <div class="row">
                                                                <div class="problemImageBox likelihoodImageBox col-xs-6">
                                                                    <div class="problemImageTitle nowrap">
                                                                        <span id="pageContent_rptProblem_lblLikelihood_0">Chance of Avalanches?</span>
                                                                    </div>
                                                                    <img id="pageContent_rptProblem_imgLikelihood_0" title="Chance of Avalanches? possible" class="img-responsive problemImages" src="Resources/Images/Likelihood/Likelihood-3_en.png" alt="Chance of Avalanches? possible" width="140" />
                                                                </div>
                                                                <div class="problemImageBox sizeImageBox col-xs-6">
                                                                    <div class="problemImageTitle nowrap">
                                                                        <span id="pageContent_rptProblem_lblSize_0">Expected Size?</span>
                                                                    </div>
                                                                    <img id="pageContent_rptProblem_imgSize_0" title="Expected Size? small - large" class="img-responsive problemImages" src="Resources/Images/Size/Size-1-3_en.png" alt="Expected Size? small - large" width="140" />
                                                                </div>
                                                            </div>
                                                        </div>
                                                    </div>
                                                    <div class="row">
                                                        <div class="problemTextBox col-xs-12">
                                                            <p>
                                                                Windslabs exist in exposed alpine areas from big winds on Friday and Saturday. Give these time to bond and be cautious if you are in steep wind affected terrain.
                                                            </p>
                                                        </div>
                                                    </div>
                                                    <div id="pageContent_rptProblem_pnlProblemTandT_0" class="row">
				
                                                        <h4 class="problemTravelTerrainheader"><span id="pageContent_rptProblem_lblProblemTravelTerrain_0">Travel and Terrain Advice</span></h4>
                                                        <div class="col-xs-12">
                                                            <div class="travelText">
                                                                <ul class='ttalist'><li>If triggered the wind slabs may step down to deeper layers resulting in large avalanches.</li><li>Be careful with wind loaded pockets, especially near ridge crests and roll-overs.</li></ul>
                                                            </div>
                                                        </div>
                                                    
			</div>
                                                
		</div>
                                                
                                            
                                                
                                                <div id="pageContent_rptProblem_pnlProblem_1" class="well">
			
                                                    
                                                    <div class="row">
                                                        <h4 class="problemheader"><span id="pageContent_rptProblem_lblProblem_1">Problem&nbsp;2: Deep Persistent Slabs</span></h4>
                                                        <div class="col-md-6">
                                                            <div class="row">
                                                                <div class=" problemImageBox elevationImageBox col-xs-6">
                                                                    <div class="problemImageTitle nowrap">
                                                                        <span id="pageContent_rptProblem_lblElevation_1">Which Elevation?</span>
                                                                    </div>
                                                                    <img id="pageContent_rptProblem_imgElevation_1" title="Which Elevation? alpine, treeline" class="img-responsive problemImages" src="Resources/Images/Elevation/Elevation-0-1-1_en.png" alt="Which Elevation? alpine, treeline" width="200" />
                                                                </div>
                                                                <div class="problemImageBox compassImageBox  col-xs-6">
                                                                    <div class="problemImageTitle nowrap">
                                                                        <span id="pageContent_rptProblem_lblAspect_1">Which Slopes?</span>
                                                                    </div>
                                                                    <img id="pageContent_rptProblem_imgAspect_1" title="Which Slopes? northeast, east, southeast, south, southwest, west, northwest, north" class="img-responsive problemImages" src="Resources/Images/Compass/compass-1-1-1-1-1-1-1-1_en.png" alt="Which Slopes? northeast, east, southeast, south, southwest, west, northwest, north" width="130" />
                                                                </div>
                                                            </div>
                                                        </div>
                                                        <div class="col-md-6">
                                                            <div class="row">
                                                                <div class="problemImageBox likelihoodImageBox col-xs-6">
                                                                    <div class="problemImageTitle nowrap">
                                                                        <span id="pageContent_rptProblem_lblLikelihood_1">Chance of Avalanches?</span>
                                                                    </div>
                                                                    <img id="pageContent_rptProblem_imgLikelihood_1" title="Chance of Avalanches? unlikely - possible" class="img-responsive problemImages" src="Resources/Images/Likelihood/Likelihood-2_en.png" alt="Chance of Avalanches? unlikely - possible" width="140" />
                                                                </div>
                                                                <div class="problemImageBox sizeImageBox col-xs-6">
                                                                    <div class="problemImageTitle nowrap">
                                                                        <span id="pageContent_rptProblem_lblSize_1">Expected Size?</span>
                                                                    </div>
                                                                    <img id="pageContent_rptProblem_imgSize_1" title="Expected Size? small - large" class="img-responsive problemImages" src="Resources/Images/Size/Size-1-5_en.png" alt="Expected Size? small - large" width="140" />
                                                                </div>
                                                            </div>
                                                        </div>
                                                    </div>
                                                    <div class="row">
                                                        <div class="problemTextBox col-xs-12">
                                                            <p>
                                                                The Nov 5 crust has facets growing above and below it, and exists up to 2500m on shady aspects and higher on solar aspects.&nbsp; We haven't seen much activity on this layer yet, but a <a href="https://avalanche.ca/mountain-information-network/submissions/1a7e5184-0f0a-4eae-b66e-bb937f0fb566" target="_blank">large avalanche</a> failed naturally on this layer on Sunday.
                                                            </p>
                                                        </div>
                                                    </div>
                                                    <div id="pageContent_rptProblem_pnlProblemTandT_1" class="row">
				
                                                        <h4 class="problemTravelTerrainheader"><span id="pageContent_rptProblem_lblProblemTravelTerrain_1">Travel and Terrain Advice</span></h4>
                                                        <div class="col-xs-12">
                                                            <div class="travelText">
                                                                <ul class='ttalist'><li>Be aware of thin areas that may propogate to deeper instabilites.</li><li>Pay attention to overhead hazards like cornices which could trigger the deep persistent slab.</li></ul>
                                                            </div>
                                                        </div>
                                                    
			</div>
                                                
		</div>
                                                
                                            
                                                </section>
                                            
                                        <div id="pageContent_pnlProblemGlossaryList">
			
                                            <a id="lnkProblemGlossaryToggle" class="btn-block" href="javascript: return void(0);">Problem Glossary</a>
                                            <div id="problemGlossary" class="bg-info">
                                                <dl>
                                                    
                                                            <dt id="pageContent_rptProblemGlossary_dtProblemGlossary_0">Dry Loose</dt>
                                                            <dd id="pageContent_rptProblemGlossary_ddProblemGlossary_0"><ul>
    <li>Are usually small, but may gain significant mass on long steep slopes.</li>
    <li>Are typically limited to steep terrain (40+ degrees).</li>
    <li>Stabilize soon after a storm, usually within a few days.</li>
</ul>
<span>Dry Loose avalanches are best managed by:</span><br />
<ul>
    <li>Avoiding terrain traps and large steep slopes until the surface has stabilized.</li>
    <li>On large steep slopes, occasionally move across the fall line to avoid being caught by your own sluffs from above.</li>
</ul></dd>
                                                        
                                                            <dt id="pageContent_rptProblemGlossary_dtProblemGlossary_1">Wet Loose</dt>
                                                            <dd id="pageContent_rptProblemGlossary_ddProblemGlossary_1"><ul>
    <li>Are more powerful than dry loose avalanches due to their higher density.</li>
    <li>Are often limited to sunny slope aspects.</li>
    <li>Are commonly confined to the warmest part of the day.</li>
</ul>
<span>Wet Loose avalanches are best managed by:</span><br />
<ul>
    <li>Avoiding start zones and avalanche paths when the snow becomes moist from daytime heating, from rain, or does not freeze overnight.</li>
</ul></dd>
                                                        
                                                            <dt id="pageContent_rptProblemGlossary_dtProblemGlossary_2">Wind Slabs</dt>
                                                            <dd id="pageContent_rptProblemGlossary_ddProblemGlossary_2"><ul>
    <li>Vary in size from small to medium.</li>
    <li>Occur on steeper lee and cross-loaded portions of slopes (typically 35+ degrees).</li>
    <li>Are often limited to specific terrain features such as lee ridge-tops.</li>
    <li>Can often be recognized by the appearance of the snow surface, changes in surface snow hardness, hollow, drum-like sounds and/or shooting cracks.</li>
    <li>Winds that vary in strength and direction can produce complex and unexpected wind slab patterns.</li>
    <li>Stabilize fairly soon, usually in a few days to a week.</li>
</ul>
<span>Wind slabs are best managed by:</span><br />
<ul>
    <li>Recognizing and avoiding areas where wind slabs have formed, until they have stabilized.</li>
</ul></dd>
                                                        
                                                            <dt id="pageContent_rptProblemGlossary_dtProblemGlossary_3">Storm Slabs</dt>
                                                            <dd id="pageContent_rptProblemGlossary_ddProblemGlossary_3"><ul>
    <li>Vary in size from small to very large.</li>
    <li>May be soft slabs, fooling people into underestimating slab potential.</li>
    <li>Tend to occur on moderately steep slopes (35+ degrees).</li>
    <li>May occur in all terrain, but are larger and more frequent in the alpine.</li>
    <li>Stabilize soon after a storm, usually within a few days.</li>
</ul>
<span>Storm slabs are best managed by:</span><br />
<ul>
    <li>Conservative terrain choices during and after storms until the storm snow has stabilized.</li>
</ul></dd>
                                                        
                                                            <dt id="pageContent_rptProblemGlossary_dtProblemGlossary_4">Wet Slabs</dt>
                                                            <dd id="pageContent_rptProblemGlossary_ddProblemGlossary_4"><ul>
    <li>Involve wet layers in the snowpack, typically including deeper layers.</li>
    <li>Tend to be large.</li>
    <li>Occur when water forms or penetrates below the surface of the snowpack.</li>
</ul>
<span>Wet slabs are best managed by:&nbsp;</span><br />
<ul>
    <li>Avoiding start zones and avalanche paths when the snow becomes wet from daytime heating, rain, or lack of an overnight freeze.</li>
</ul></dd>
                                                        
                                                            <dt id="pageContent_rptProblemGlossary_dtProblemGlossary_5">Persistent Slabs</dt>
                                                            <dd id="pageContent_rptProblemGlossary_ddProblemGlossary_5"><ul>
    <li>Slide on buried persistent weak layers, which often form during clear periods and may involve deeper layers from multiple storms.</li>
    <li>Vary in size from medium to very large and may cross terrain barriers to involve multiple slide paths.</li>
    <li>May occur on very gentle terrain, even slopes of 20 degrees or less.</li>
    <li>May be localized to specific elevations, aspects, or regions.</li>
    <li>There are often no visible signs of persistent slab instability.</li>
    <li>Lack of avalanche activity and lack of danger signs are NOTreliable indicators of stability.</li>
    <li>Compression tests and Rutschblock tests may locate persistent weak layers.</li>
    <li>Stabilize slowly, tending to persist for several weeks or longer.</li>
    <li>Often have dormant periods, becoming active again when the weather changes.</li>
    <li>Are prone to lingering pockets of instability that persist long after most areas have stabilized.</li>
    <li>Tend to release above the trigger, making it difficult to escape.</li>
    <li>Are often triggered remotely from a long distance away.</li>
</ul>
<span>Persistent slabs are best managed by:</span><br />
<ul>
    <li>Very conservative terrain choices.</li>
    <li>Allow extra time for persistent slabs to stabilize and use a very cautious approach to new terrain. Be especially cautious after storms or during warming periods.</li>
</ul></dd>
                                                        
                                                            <dt id="pageContent_rptProblemGlossary_dtProblemGlossary_6">Deep Persistent Slabs</dt>
                                                            <dd id="pageContent_rptProblemGlossary_ddProblemGlossary_6"><ul>
    <li>Slide on deeply buried persistent weak layers, which often form during clear periods or rain-on-snow events early in the season.</li>
    <li>Involve thick, hard slabs, sometimes the entire snowpack.</li>
    <li>Tend to be very large, commonly cross terrain barriers to involve multiple slide paths.</li>
    <li>Tend to occur on larger slopes of moderate steepness, typically 30-40 degrees.</li>
    <li>May be localized to specific elevations, aspects, or regions.</li>
    <li>There are often no visible signs of persistent deep slab instability.</li>
    <li>Lack of avalanche activity and lack of danger signs are NOT reliable indicators of stability.</li>
    <li>Stabilize slowly if at all, persisting for months and often the entire season.</li>
    <li>Dormant persistent deep slab instabilities often become active again when the weather changes, especially after storms or with warm spring weather.</li>
    <li>Tend to release above the trigger, making it difficult to escape.</li>
    <li>Are often triggered remotely from a long distance away.</li>
</ul>
<p>Deep persistent slabs are best managed by:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Very conservative terrain choices and a very cautious approach to new terrain.</li>
    <li>Be especially cautious after storms or during warming periods.</li>
</ul></dd>
                                                        
                                                            <dt id="pageContent_rptProblemGlossary_dtProblemGlossary_7">Cornices</dt>
                                                            <dd id="pageContent_rptProblemGlossary_ddProblemGlossary_7"><ul>
    <li>May trigger large slab avalanches on relatively stable slopes below.</li>
    <li>Are often associated with recent wind loading and/or temperature changes.</li>
    <li>Can be triggered from ridges, sometimes breaking surprisingly far back onto ridge tops.</li>
</ul>
<p>Cornices are best managed by:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Approaching corniced ridges cautiously.</li>
    <li>Avoid travelling on or near overhanging cornices and limit time spent exposed to slopes below cornices, especially soon after wind events and during periods of warming temperatures.</li>
</ul></dd>
                                                        
                                                </dl>
                                            </div>
                                        
		</div>
                                    
	</div>
                                </div>
                            </details>
                            <details id="details2">
                                <summary>Forecast Details</summary>
                                <div class="container-fluid">
                                    <div class="well">
                                        <div class="row">
                                            <h4 class="blackBg whiteText">
                                                Weather Forecast
                                            </h4>
                                            <div class="col-sm-12">
                                                <p class="p_CC664AAA"><span class="s_AA239A9B">Dry and warm conditions for the next few days. Monday, we may see up to 5 cm of new snow, with winds increasing to strong SW. Tuesday will be dry with decreasing winds from the NW. On Wednesday we may see warm alpine temperatures and the possibility of an inversion. </span></p><p class="p_CC664AAA"><span class="s_AA239A9B"> </span></p>
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                    </div>
                                    <div class="well">
                                        <div class="row">
                                            <h4 class="blackBg whiteText">
                                                Snowpack Discussion
                                            </h4>
                                            <div class="col-sm-12">
                                                <p class="p_CC664AAA"><span class="s_AA239A9B">Variable surface conditions exist with hard windslabs in exposed locations and softer snow in more sheltered areas. The Nov 5 facet/crust combo is down 50-80 cm and producing variable test results, but 'sudden' in fracture character. This crust extends up to 2500 m on N aspects and higher on solar aspects. Snow depths at treeline are 70-130 cm.</span></p>
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                    </div>
                                    <div class="well">
                                        <div class="row">
                                            <h4 class="blackBg whiteText">
                                                Avalanche Activity Discussion
                                            </h4>
                                            <div class="col-sm-12">
                                                <p class="p_CC664AAA"><span class="s_AA239A9B">Minimal avalanche activity observed today at local ski hills and on a ski tour in the Watermelon Peak area. The exception to this was a large </span><a href="https://avalanche.ca/mountain-information-network/submissions/1a7e5184-0f0a-4eae-b66e-bb937f0fb566" target="_blank"><span class="s_9255B882">avalanche</span></a><span class="s_AA239A9B"> that was witnessed at around 11 am by a member of the public on the west aspect of Dolomite Peak. It was a size 2.5 that ran in a cross loaded gully feature with minimal weather inputs to trigger it</span></p>
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                    </div>

                                </div>
                            </details>

                ToggleWeatherObsLearn();
            });

            $("#alpineCollapsedBox, #treelineCollapsedBox, #belowtreelineCollapsedBox").on({
                mouseover: function () {
                    $(this).removeClass("expandableBox").addClass("dangerRateExpandedBox");
                },
                mouseout: function () {
                    $(this).removeClass("dangerRateExpandedBox").addClass("expandableBox");
                },
                click: function () {
                    $(this).toggleClass("dangerRateExpandedBox").toggleClass("expandableBox");
                }
            });

            $('.tabpanels').css("min-height", "0px");

           

        });

        $(document).on("wb-updated.wb-tabs", ".wb-tabs", function (event, displayedPanel) {

            var tabNum = "tab%3d1";
            if ($(displayedPanel).get(0).id == "details2")
            {
                tabNum = "tab%3d2";
            }
            $('.lnkPrint').get(0).href = $('.lnkPrint').get(0).href.replace("tab%3d1", tabNum);
            $('.lnkPrint').get(0).href = $('.lnkPrint').get(0).href.replace("tab%3d2", tabNum);

        });

        function ToggleConfidenceDefinition() {
            $("#confidenceDefinition").toggle();
            return false;
        }

        function ToggleProblemGlossary() {
            $("#problemGlossary").toggle();
            return false;
        }

        function ToggleDangerRatingDefinition() {
            $("#dangerRatingDefinition").toggle();
            return false;
        }
        function ToggleWeatherObsLearn() {
            $("#tblWeatherObservations").toggle();
            return false;
        }
        //Only works for IE & Firefox
        $("body").bind("onbeforeprint", function () {
            $("#problemGlossary").hide();
            $("#lnkProblemGlossaryToggle").hide();
        });

    </script>


    

    
    <section id="modalPopup" class="mfp-hide modal-dialog modal-content overlay-def">
        <header class="modal-header">
            <h2 class="modal-title"><span id="modalTitle"></span></h2>
            <div id="additionalModalHeaderInfo"></div>
        </header>
        <div class="modal-body">
            <div id="modalContent">

            </div>
        </div>
    </section>

</body>
</html>
